this is a classic review
it's a classic review Virginia hip hop
duo Clipse
originally a brotherly two-piece that
dates back to the early 90s founded by
rappers malice now known as no malice as
well as Pusha T and part of my reasoning
behind doing this review isn't just that
it's a great album of course it is but
also despite everyone involved in clips
and their success having such a large
profile in the music industry today much
larger than they did when the duo
initially started I still feel like
clips goes under the radar for a lot of
young rap fans for some reason I get
that the bling era isn't the most
celebrated in the 40 years of hip-hop's
history but clips are one of the most
groundbreaking and enigmatic duo's to
ever grace the genre and I'm hoping that
with records like this turning 20 years
old soon that we can have a bit of a
reassessment and realize that look there
are legitimate reasons as to why clips
are not as popular as I think they
should be for one their catalog would be
a lot more impressive if not for every
force in the universe
trying to prevent clips from happening
as monstrously talented as Pusha was as
malice was as williams was as an
up-and-coming producer one half of The
Neptunes around the time that he met
clips he went to bat for them they got a
deal
on Elektra Records and the only thing
that ended up happening is that the
album was shelved and they were dropped
from the label it wouldn't be until the
early 2000s that the duo would be
supported by Williams through his star
track imprint then they quickly grinded
out a proper debut album with Lord
willin in 2002 even though the album is
a little rough around the edges on the
best tracks everything that would make
Clips a special group was here in spades
the slick flows the cold blooded
attitude the coke talk and terminology
the artful and funny word planned
Andras as well as Williams one-of-a-kind

sounding like I don't know something off

because the wordplay the rhyme patterns
the raw ass hooks on this record were so

this record as well as hell hath no fury
were eerily similar however that was not
to their detriment their chemistry
basically amounted to coming on tracks
and reinforcing one another's unique rap
style that they essentially forged being
tightly knit collaborators it was
something that was easy to digest given

sounded or wrapped like push a tee and
vice versa
now on Lord willin Clips hit it pretty

the story of clips does not necessarily

marked by the
rest of the duo's manager Anthony

really do

it's got a great energy a great groove

essentially are evangelizing with their

drug dealers saying they should
collective eyes instead of killing each

sounds like what I would imagine it

the cars are big the cribs are bigger

the soundtrack to grinding on the lower

here nightmares which is a very dreary

Pusha and malice essentially detail some

guilt they feel leading or at least
rapping about the lifestyles they do the
guilt and paranoia that hangs in your
head when all the noise of
the money the parties the drinks that
everything kind of quiets down which
seemed to work as a white noise machine
just blasting away at the highest volume
so you don't hear the quiet anxieties
that are just kind of eating away at you
in the background at least until it's
too late which in the case of clips may
have in fact been the case which is why
we no longer have clips so in conclusion
I guess there are a lot of great
takeaways from this record on multiple
levels not only lyrical talent
incredibly unique and fun instrumentals
messages of unity messages of going out
there and doing it for yourself
tomorrow's not promised but also a
warning to not let a fast lifestyle
catch you up in a way where you're not
paying attention to what could be going
on around you what could be hurting
those you love those who are close to
you because everything that you've built
up for years and years and years could
be quickly knocked down and disappear
